Disclaimer
The figures, projections, and savings estimates presented in this executive summary are 
illustrative only and based on preliminary modeling assumptions. Actual performance, 
economics, and savings will vary based on:

Final system design and engineering specifications

On-site inspection findings and structural/electrical constraints

Actual utility rate structures, tariff changes, and billing practices

Real-world weather conditions, shading, and system performance

Changes in energy consumption patterns

All values are subject to revision and will be finalized upon completion of site assessment, 
engineering review, and execution of definitive agreements. This summary does not 
constitute a binding offer or guarantee of system performance or financial outcomes.

Redland Baptist Church Solar PPA Executive Summary 4

Thanks for sharing the document. Here's how I suggest we present a clean, professional version of the **Redland Baptist Church Solar PPA Executive Summary** for client presentation. The deck will be titled:

---

### **Redland Baptist Church: Solar PPA Executive Summary**
#### Project Overview, Economic Scenarios & Key Performance Metrics

---

#### Proposed Slide Outline:

1. **Introduction & Project Overview**  
   - Purpose of solar PPA  
   - Overview of modeling assumptions (e.g., 0.5% PV degradation, PEPCO 2025-2030 projection)

2. **Key Metrics & Baseline Data**  
   - Energy usage, modeled PV output, utility vs. PPA rates, Year-1 savings

3. **PEPCO Rate Projections vs. PPA Rates**  
   - Comparative table of PEPCO and PPA rates, annual savings

4. **Scenario A: PPA with 2% Escalator**  
   - Year-by-year breakdown of payments, savings vs. utility baseline

5. **Scenario B: Fixed PPA Rate**  
   - Year-by-year breakdown with fixed pricing

6. **Production Model Summary**  
   - System size, performance ratio, yield, Year-1 production

7. **Monthly Production vs. Usage (Chart)**  
   - Visualization of solar generation vs. load

8. **Disclaimer & Key Considerations**  
   - Assumptions, variables, and caveats in projection

---

Should I proceed with generating the first slide (**Introduction & Project Overview**) for client presentation?

slidecode.title: Redland Baptist Church Solar PPA Overview
slidecode.subtitle: Project Summary & Modeling Context

body.description: Implement a solar Power Purchase Agreement (PPA) to reduce electricity costs and environmental impact while preserving upfront capital.
PEPCO rate projections (2025–2030), 0.5% annual PV degradation, and zero export value were factored into cost and savings scenarios.
Projected system size of approximately 266 kW producing 301,745 kWh in Year 1 with a performance ratio of 0.87.
Present decision-makers with an informed analysis of cost-benefit under varying PPA structures, supporting long-term energy planning.

slidecode.talktrack:
The objective of this solar PPA project is both financial and environmental—delivering lower energy costs and a reduced carbon footprint, all without the need for Redland Baptist Church to deploy upfront capital. This slide introduces the scope and methodology of the executive summary.

Key assumptions like the 0.5% annual PV degradation and PEPCO's projected energy rate escalation through 2030 are critical to the modeling framework. These ensure the projections are grounded in regional utility trends.

Ultimately, this summary offers a structured look at economic tradeoffs across different PPA pricing scenarios. It's designed to empower stakeholders with data-backed insights for making confident, strategic energy decisions.

parts: {"data":{"image_url":"https://slidesgpt.com/api/media/539285d21d9c","presentation_view_url":"https://slidesgpt.com/view/240eb8c8NaN0d4"}}

slidecode.title: Key Metrics & Baseline Data
slidecode.subtitle: Foundational Figures for PPA Modeling

body.description: Redland's 12-month baseline consumption is 293,975 kWh, setting the reference for energy cost and solar offset analysis.
Projected solar generation is 301,745 kWh in Year 1, exceeding baseline demand, and degrades at 0.5% annually.
The baseline utility cost is $0.2031/kWh, compared to a Year-1 PPA rate of $0.1630/kWh under the escalating scenario.
Customer cost under the PPA is $56,918 in Year 1, generating $2,817 in savings compared to utility rates.

slidecode.talktrack:
This slide lays out the core performance and financial metrics that form the basis of the solar PPA analysis. The baseline electricity usage of nearly 294,000 kWh per year anchors the assessment of how much solar can offset.

With the system expected to produce over 301,000 kWh in its first year, it not only matches but slightly exceeds annual demand. This positions the project for significant offset, even as the system degrades modestly over time.

By locking into a lower initial PPA rate of $0.1630/kWh, the Church achieves immediate savings—over $2,800 in Year 1 alone—against utility rates forecasted to increase. These metrics demonstrate that even in the early phase, the economic case for solar is compelling.

parts: {"data":{"image_url":"https://slidesgpt.com/api/media/ca77128185ab","presentation_view_url":"https://slidesgpt.com/view/240eb8c8NaN0d4"}}

slidecode.title: PEPCO Projections vs. PPA Rates
slidecode.subtitle: Cost Trends from 2025 to 2030

body.description: PEPCO's projected rates increase from $0.2100 in 2025 to $0.2928/kWh by 2030, representing a 39% cumulative rise.
The PPA begins at $0.1630/kWh with a 2% annual escalator, reaching only $0.1800/kWh by 2030—a much flatter curve.
Savings grow from $0.0470/kWh in 2025 to $0.1128/kWh in 2030, translating to 22.4%–38.5% cost reduction annually.
The PPA structure offers predictable pricing, insulating the Church from volatile and rising utility rates.

slidecode.talktrack:
This comparison highlights the fundamental economic advantage of a solar PPA versus remaining on utility power alone. PEPCO's rates are projected to increase sharply over the next five years—from $0.2100 to nearly $0.2930/kWh. In contrast, the PPA rate only grows modestly, preserving long-term affordability.

The year-by-year analysis underscores how savings accelerate over time. While initial savings are already respectable at 22%, they expand beyond 38% by 2030. This trendline strengthens the case for early adoption.

Perhaps most importantly, the PPA acts as a hedge—offering cost certainty and financial control in an environment where energy pricing can be unpredictable and inflationary.

{"data":{"image_url":"https://slidesgpt.com/api/media/6d44af672c8a","presentation_view_url":"https://slidesgpt.com/view/240eb8c8NaN0d4"}}

slidecode.title: PEPCO Projections vs. PPA Rates
slidecode.subtitle: 2025–2030 Comparative Electricity Pricing

body.description: Energy-only rates expected to rise from $0.2100/kWh in 2025 to $0.2928/kWh by 2030, based on utility projections.
PPA starts at $0.1630/kWh in 2025 with a 2% annual increase, reaching $0.1800/kWh by 2030—well below PEPCO rates.
Annual savings rise from $0.0470/kWh (22.4%) in 2025 to $0.1128/kWh (38.5%) in 2030 under the PPA structure.
PPA structure offers long-term protection from utility inflation, enabling consistent budgeting and energy cost control.

slidecode.talktrack:
This slide presents a clear side-by-side comparison of the expected evolution of electricity rates under PEPCO and the proposed PPA. The PEPCO forecast shows a steady increase in utility rates—climbing nearly 40% from 2025 to 2030. These projections form the baseline against which the PPA's value is evaluated.

The PPA, in contrast, begins at a significantly lower rate and increases only marginally over the same period. Even with its 2% escalator, the PPA remains far more affordable, reaching just $0.1800 by 2030.

This widening gap in price trajectories translates into increasing savings for Redland Baptist Church year after year. More importantly, the fixed nature of the PPA introduces financial stability—a strategic hedge against future energy inflation.

slidecode.title: Scenario A: PPA with 2% Escalator
slidecode.subtitle: Annual Costs and Savings (2026–2030)

body.description: Annual PPA payments grow from $49,917 in 2026 to $52,960 in 2030, tracking the 2% escalation schedule.
Supplemental utility imports range from $9,901 to $11,146 annually, ensuring full energy coverage.
Total annual costs (PPA + imports) rise from $59,818 in 2026 to $64,106 by 2030, still well below utility baseline.
Savings improve yearly—from $16,616 in 2026 to $21,970 in 2030—totaling over $96,000 across five years.

slidecode.talktrack:
This scenario models a PPA starting at $0.1630/kWh with a 2% annual escalator, reflecting a common contract structure for long-term solar agreements. Even with modest rate growth, the PPA remains financially advantageous.

The Church's payments rise gradually from just under $50,000 in 2026 to roughly $53,000 by 2030. When utility imports are included, total costs range from $59,818 to $64,106 annually—consistently lower than projected utility bills.

Crucially, the savings compound each year as PEPCO rates increase. Cumulatively, this adds up to more than $96,000 in avoided costs over five years, supporting both fiscal stewardship and long-term sustainability.
